Literature Review: Viral membrane fusion is a crucial event in the replication cycle of enveloped viruses, allowing them to release their genome into the host cell interior. The fusion process is mediated by dedicated fusion proteins or fusion complexes, which are essential for the successful infection of host cells. In this review, we will discuss the current understanding of viral membrane fusion proteins, including their triggering mechanisms, structural intermediates, and interplay with lipid bilayers. We will also explore cellular and therapeutic interventions that can thwart virus-cell membrane fusion.
